content.description:
This route goes up the East face of the Honey Comb spire on cobles and shallow pockets.  Avoid

Honey Crack

to the right and stay to the right of the left edge of the spire.  The bottom is easy-going up cobbles, etc.  At the top (crux) where the face narrows between the crack and arete, avoid the temptation to use the crack and make a few long reaches for a shallow pocket, then there is a nice jug on the top to finish.  Many of these holds on the upper part are sharp!
content.protection: There is one bolt on top of the spire that can be used for a TR along with gear in the main wall (mid sized cam works)

content.description: Around the corner from the spire is an arete with a big boulder at its base.  On the next north-facing wall from this arete is the climb, recognized by the crack on the upper face.  Scramble up the ledges to the crack and do the few fun moves.
content.protection: Only a few fist-sized pieces are needed for the few moves.  Perhaps some more pro to set an anchor on top.

content.description:
Start from the corner block South of the Honeycomb Spire.  Up the left side of the North-facing wall, to the bolt on top shared with

Rhinocerock

.
content.protection:
Single bolt for TR.  Back this up with trad gear or the bolt on top of

Rhinocerock

about 4 feet away.

content.description: South of the Honeycomb Spire is a corner block with a single bolt on top of the cliff.  Rhinocerock goes up the right side of the East-facing wall on the South side of the corner block.
content.protection:
Top rope.  A single bolt on top can be backed up with trad gear, or to the bolt on

Rosebud

about 4 feet away.

content.description:
Face climb a few feet right of

Deathwidth

.  Avoid the edge of the crack.
content.protection:
We dropped a top rope from

Deathwidth

.

content.description: On the east side of the Honeycomb Spire is a meandering crack that starts on the lower right side of the tower and traverses to the center where it is vertical for a few moves.  Many face holds help for the feet while a few jams in the crack are needed to ascend the vertical section.  The rock is a little loose and has lots of lichen growing on it.
content.protection: Standard rack.  The single bolt on top of the tower should be backed up if used for an anchor.  A horizontal crack on the main wall will accept mid-sized cams to facilitate an anchor.

content.description: A few crimpy finger holds are the crux below the top of the arete (corner).
content.protection: Top rope- single bolt on top of the honeycomb spire.  Backup with rope or sling to main cliff.
content.location: This is the Northeast (right side of the spire when facing it) arete of the spire.

climbs.name: Hippopromis
climbs.fa: Tom and Rob Hanson, Lynn Ankele, '86.

content.description: Around the corner from the spire to the southeast is an arete with a large boulder at the base.  On the adjacent wall is a fun toprope following a black water streak up the wall.
content.protection: There is a single bolt at the top, back it up with some more pro.

content.description:
This is the face route left of

Deathwidth

.
content.protection:
Top rope. 1 bolt on top, of

Deathwidth

.  Use trad gear for backup and to rig for Collage.

content.description: Just North of the spire there is a wide recessed chimney on the main wall.  Set up a top rope and grovel up the chimney which may be a squeeze for bigger people.
content.protection: There's a single bolt above the climb on the cliff top to help set it up.  Back this up with some gear.

content.description:
Scramble up the start next to

Serpentine Crack

, but stay in the corner to the right. Pass a few small tree as you zipper this little trad route up the crack.

The crux is the second tiny ledge just under the small tree.

Beta: hand jam with left-leaning laybacks worked for me the whole way until I could mantel the ledges. My feet stayed smeared on the classic Castlewood mini-cobblestone, and I barely need to find foot holds.

I used a BD cams #3 , #0.75, #1, a #4 hex, and carried a rack up to a #3.

I can’t be the first to have climbed this? If you know, I’ll take it down. Otherwise, enjoy Choss Me The Moss!
content.protection: There are no anchors. We had to improvise a little, but there are plenty of teas anchor options to set up a TR.
content.location: The easiest way to get there is to use the GPS location, but honestly park in the lot, and head Northeast to the canyons. Then head north until you find a pillar with a lone bolt... there are some shady bolts and a bunch of places to scramble down.

climbs.name: Brain Drain
climbs.fa: [S. Sills& T. Hanson  as an ice climb, 1989?, T. Hanson, 1989]

content.description: The NE facing dihedral next to the arete with routes on either side.  Nothing too tricky here, just some fun climbing with stemming, jams, and a few face holds.  Note:  Although it is a little damp in dry periods it is still not a big problem.  I wouldn't recommend this during the spring or any other wet time.
content.protection: Standard rack.  Some medium to large pieces would be helpful.

pathTokens: Denver Metropolitan Area Bouldering and Buildering
